questions.text: A 34 year old male presented with complaints of burning and itching over thigh with skin lesion. There was a history of painkiller tablet consumption before 1 day. Similar history of skin lesion over the same site before 2 years. The condition shown in the image is?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is Fixed drug eruption. It occurs at the same site on repeat exposure of drug. It is common due to NSAIDS (Option D)

Option A- Tinea corporis is erythematous scaly annular lesions cause by dermatophyte infection. It is associated with itching

Option B- Granuloma annulare is a common inflammatory skin condition typified clinically by annular, smooth, discoloured papules and plaques, and necrobiotic granulomas on histology.

Option C- BT leprosy lesions are erythematous asymmetric plaques with satellite lesions associated with decreased touch temperature sensation over plaque.

Tag: Drug reaction

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, page number:118.11

questions.text: A 40 year old male farmer presented with growth as shown below. There was a history of penetrating trauma. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chromoblastomycosis (Verrucous dermatitis)

  • Causative agent: Pigmented (Dematiaceous fungi)
    • Fonsecaea pedrosoii
    • Phialophora verrucosum
  • Clinical feature: Rough warty, cauliflower like lesions over exposed (trauma prone) sites. m\c on foot (Trauma prone site)→(Choice B)
  • Histopathology shows medlar / sclerotic bodies/ copper penny bodies
  • Treatment: Itraconazole

Option A- Sporotrichosis (Rose gardener's disease/ rose thorn disease)



Option C- Mycetoma


Madura foot also known as Mycetoma

It is characterized by the triad of

  • Painless firm mass
  • Multiple sinus
  • Purulent discharge containing grains

Option D-

Warts are benign lesions that occur in the mucosa and skin. Warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). The common wart may appear as a papular growth with an irregular contour and surface.

Source: Chromoblastomycosis

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number: 32.77

questions.text: A 34 year male patient presented with silvery white scaling over elbow and knees. There was history of winter aggravation in skin lesions. All of the following nail changes can be seen in this patient, except:
questions.solution:
Mees' Lines are a change that occurs in the colour of the nail with no palpable ridges, typically described as white bands traversing the nail bed, running parallel to the lunula across the entire nail bed of the individual.

This finding is indicative of arsenic, thallium or other heavy metal poisonings.

Clinical signs of nail bed involvement

  • Oil-drop sign and salmon patch (Pathognomic of nail psoriasis) - Choice D
  • Onycholysis - typically with a pink zone proximally
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis - Choice A
  • Splinter haemorrhages under the distal third of the nail plate

Clinical signs of nail matrix involvement

  • Coarse Pitting (Most Common manifestation) - Choice B
  • Leukonychia
  • Red spots in lunula
  • Onychorrhexis (longitudinal nail ridge, split, or fissure)
  • Beau lines (transverse lines and ridges)
  • Nail crumbling

Nail Psoriasis Severity Index (NAPSI) is a scoring tool for nail psoriasis.

Tag: Nail Psoriasis

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:35.14

questions.text: A child presented with bluish red, subcutaneous swellings over the cervical region for several months. Some of the lesions underwent spontaneous healing leaving typical, cord-like scars. Infection of underlying cervical lymph nodes is present. Histology showed marked caseating necrosis. What will be diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Scrofuloderma

Multibacillary type of cutaneous tuberculosis.

  • It develops as infection into the skin from an underlying focus, usually lymph nodes and occasionally bone, joint.
  • MC in children.
  • MC lymph node involved: Cervical lymph node
  • Begins as asymptomatic, bluish red, subcutaneous swellings that persist for several months and overlie an infected gland or joint.
  • Numerous fistulae may intercommunicate beneath ridges of a bluish skin and some may open draining sinuses onto the skin surface.
  • Spontaneous healing can occur, but the course is very protracted and leaves typical, cord like scars.

Histology shows marked caseating necrosis, in which there are usually numerous bacteria.

Choice B- Lupus vulgaris


  • Erythematous/Violaceous [purplish] plaque with central scarring [Central clearing is seen in Tinea; Central crusting is seen in Leishmaniasis].
  • On diascopy (pressing of the lesion with glass slide) Golden brown, Apple jelly nodules are seen at the periphery of the lesion.

Choice C- Erythema Nodosum


Presents as Erythematous nodules over anterior leg which ulcerate.

Choice D- Ecthyma Gangrenosum


  • Indurated lesion with necrotic crust → on removal → forms ulcer.

Three types

  • Ecthyma gangrenosum: Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Ecthyma pyogenicum: Strep, Staph aureus
  • Ecthyma contagiosum/Contagious pustular disease/Orf disease- Parapoxvirus/ ORF virus.

Source: Scrofuloderma

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:27.15

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image
questions.solution:
Melanoma (the most malignant skin cancer), melanocytic nevi (the most common benign skin tumor) (Choice D), and dysplastic nevi (in between nevi and melanoma) all result from melanocytes.

Melanoma, also redundantly known as malignant melanoma, is a type of skin cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes

  • A is for Asymmetry.
  • B is for Border. Melanoma borders tend to be uneven and may have scalloped or notched edges.
  • C is for Color. Multiple colors are a warning sign.
  • D is for Diameter: If the size of the lesion is 6 mm or larger.
  • E is for Evolving. Any change in size, shape, color or elevation, or any new symptom in it, such as bleeding, itching or crusting, may be a warning sign of melanoma.

 

Option B- BCC typically presents as a shiny, pink- or flesh-colored papule or nodule with surface telangiectasia. The tumor may enlarge and ulcerate, giving the borders a rolled or rodent ulcer appearance.

Option C- Squamous cell carcinoma has a precursor lesion, actinic keratosis, which exhibits tumor progression. Primary risk factor is UV solar radiation.

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:143.7

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented with multiple nodular lesions all over body. There was palmar and axillary freckling. Family history was positive in father. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Patient in the image is showing multiple neurofibromas and Palmar freckling.
  • Family history in father is also positive pointing towards diagnosis of NF-1
  • NF 1 is also known as Von recklinghausen's disease

Option A- Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant disorder of multisystem hamartomatosis

It contains-

  • Epilepsy
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Mental retardation

It is also known as EpiLoiA

Epi- Epilepsy

Loi- Low IQ

A- Adenoma sebaceum

Other cutaneous manifestations include ash leaf macule, shagreen patch, and periungual fibroma

Option C- Darier disease is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder classified as a hereditary acantholytic dermatosis. Darier disease typically presents with scaly crusted papules in a seborrhoeic distribution and in skin folds.

Option D- Cowden disease

A rare inherited disorder marked by the presence of many benign growths called hamartomas and an increased risk of cancer.

Tag: Neurofibromatosis

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:80.2; Updated diagnostic criteria for NF 1 (2021)

questions.text: The image is showing patchy hair loss in a 16 year old female. What is the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Trichotillomania

  • Trichotillomania (TTM) also known as hair-pulling disorder,
  • Trichotillomania is part of OCD and is thought to be largely related to anxiety disorders.
  • More common in females of adolescent age group.
  • Classical tonsular appearance (Friar tuck appearance)
  • Sometimes traumatic pulling of hair can lead to bleeding.
  • Trichoscopy of trichotillomania is characterized by presence of hairs broken at different length, black dots, trichoptilosis, coiled hairs, flame hairs, V-sign and tulip hairs.

Option B: Alopecia areata

  • Autoimmune lymphocytic damage pigmented hair leading to hair loss.
  • Patient presents with smooth bald patch with sparing of greyhair.
  • On dermoscopy, there is classical exclamation hair.
  • In histopathology, lymphocytic infiltration around hair follicle (Swarm of bees appearance) is seen
  • There are three main types of alopecia areata:

Option C: Tinea capitis

It is dermatophyte infection of hair. It occurs predominantly in prepubertal children.

The clinical features may be broadly categorised into non-inflammatory and inflammatory variants.

Option D: FPHL

Female pattern hair loss usually presents as thinning rather than patchy loss and typically occurs in older individuals. Widening of the central part is seen.

Key takeaway:

  • trichotillomania (TTM) also known as hair-pulling disorder,
  • Trichotillomania is part of OCD and is thought to be largely related to anxiety disorders. More common in females of adolescent age group.
  • Classical tonsular appearance (Friar tuck appearance)
  • Trichoscopy of trichotillomania is characterized by the presence of hairs broken at different lengths, black dots, trichoptilosis, coiled hairs, flame hairs, V-sign and tulip hairs.

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 86.17

questions.text: What skin condition is characterized by the presence of coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp?
questions.solution:
• Etiological agent: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Lesions of erythrasma are asymptomatic, erythematous to hyperpigmented. Occurs in the axilla, groin or inframammary area.
  • Colors on wood's lamp:
  • Erythrasma- Coral red
  • P.Vesicolor- Yellow
  • Tinea capitis(Microsporum sp.)- Blue-Green
  • Tinea capitis( T. schoenleinii)- Dull blue
  • Vitiligo- Chalky white

Option B, C and D : They do not show fluorescence on wood's lamp examination.

Key Takeaway :

Erythrasma is characterized by coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp, caused by the bacterium Corynebacterium minutissimum. It typically presents as asymptomatic, erythematous to hyperpigmented lesions in areas like the axilla, groin, or inframammary folds

Tag:

Must know

Erythrasma

INI Nov 2022

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 26.40

questions.text: A 48 year old female patient presented with burning pain associated with fluid filled lesions over right shoulder. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Painful vesicles in a grouped manner in dermatomal distribution is suggestive of Herpes zoster.

Herpes Zoster :

  • Reactivation of varicella.
  • Eruptive phase lesions : Unilateral
  • Dermatomal, Painful grouped vesicles over red base.
  • Complication : Post herpetic neuralgia (allodynia is seen).

Option A : Molluscum contagiosum present as asymptomatic white to skin colored umbilicated small papules.

Option C : Chicken pox present as fever with polymorphic lesions over erythematous base over trunk (Dew drop on rose petal appearance).

Option D : Herpes simplex is not related to dermatomal distribution. usually present as vesicles or crust around lips and oral erosions. Or it can present as genital erosions.

Key Takeaway :

Zoster :

  • Reactivation of varicella.
  • Eruptive phase lesions : Unilateral
  • Dermatomal, Painful grouped vesicles over red base.
  • Complication : Post herpetic neuralgia (allodynia is seen).

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 25.27

questions.text: What is the long term complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Congenital Melanocytic Nevi:
    • The image likely shows a hyperpigmented patch with increased hair growth, consistent with congenital melanocytic nevi. When these nevi exceed 20 cm in size, they are termed giant melanocytic nevi.
  • Long-Term Complication:
    • The primary long-term risk associated with congenital melanocytic nevi, especially giant ones, is the potential for malignant transformation into melanoma. This risk necessitates careful monitoring of the nevus for any changes in size, shape, color, or texture.

Rule of ABCDE for Melanoma:

  • A - Asymmetry: One half does not match the other.
  • B - Borders: Irregular or poorly defined edges.
  • C - Color: Varied colors within the mole.
  • D - Diameter: Larger than 6 mm.
  • E - Evolution: Any change in the nevus over time.

Option B, C & D : Other options like B. Cataract, C. Loss of vision, and D. Glaucoma are not directly associated with congenital melanocytic nevi and pertain more to ocular health rather than skin lesions.

Key Takeaway

The long-term complication of congenital melanocytic nevi, particularly giant nevi, is the potential for malignant transformation into melanoma. Careful monitoring for changes in size, shape, color, or texture is essential to detect any signs of malignancy early.

Reference: Rook's textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:143

questions.text: What is the most likely metal deficiency associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Zinc is the cofactor for over 100 enzymes and as such is involved in all major metabolic pathways.
  • Patients with mutations in the intestinal zinc specific transporter, SLC30A2 develop acrodermatitis enteropathica characterized by diarrhea and severe periorificial dermatitis.
  • Diagnostic tests include a low zinc level followed by DNA testing.
  • Treatment includes high doses of zinc sulfate.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page Number: 3587

questions.text: Which characteristic nail finding of Psoriasis vulgaris is being shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows subungual hyperkeratosis

In subungual hyperkeratosis, there is excessive proliferation of nail bed, seen in psoriasis and onychomycosis.

Other changes seen in psoriasis are nail pitting, oil drop sign, onycholysis. (Option B & D)

Auspitz sign is seen in psoriasis where removal of scales lead to pinpoint bleeding. (Option A)

Option B : Oil Drop sign -

Key Takeaway :

Nail Psoriasis Mnemonic - POISON

P - Pitting (Coarse Irregular)

Oi - Oil drop sign

S - Subungual hyperkeratosis

O - Onycholysis

N - Nail dystrophy

Tags :

  1. Psoriasis
  2. Must know
  3. Ini Nov 2021, NEET 2022

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 35.14

questions.text: Which diagnostic method is particularly useful for identifying sub-clinical lesions of Malassezia infections?
questions.solution:
• Wood's Lamp Examination is effective in identifying sub-clinical lesions by revealing fluorescence in affected areas, particularly in cases of pityriasis versicolor caused by Malassezia.
  • The fluorescence observed under the Wood's Lamp can highlight scaly lesions that are not easily noticeable, making it a crucial tool for early detection.
  • Histopathological Examination, while confirming diagnosis by identifying fungal elements in tissue, may not effectively visualize subtle or sub-clinical lesions.
  • PCR Fingerprinting is primarily employed for species identification and epidemiological studies; it is not designed for visualizing sub-clinical lesions.
  • Lymphocyte Blastogenesis assesses immune response to infections but does not provide a direct method for visualizing or diagnosing lesions.

Why Not Others:

  • b) Histopathological Examination: Useful for confirming a diagnosis but may miss sub-clinical manifestations that Wood's Lamp can detect.
  • c) PCR Fingerprinting: Not focused on visualizing lesions; it serves a different diagnostic purpose related to species identification.
  • d) Lymphocyte Blastogenesis: Measures immune response but does not visualize lesions, making it unsuitable for this context.

Key Takeaways:

  • Wood's Lamp Examination is a valuable tool for identifying both clinical and sub-clinical lesions of Malassezia infections.
  • This method enhances the detection of infections that might otherwise remain unnoticed, aiding in timely diagnosis and treatment.

REFERENCE: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander. Chapter 7: Malasseziosis page number:135

Classical lesion of erythema multiforme is target lesion / bull's eye lesion

It has three concentric areas.

Etiology:

  • Idiopathic
  • viral infection (Herpes simplex, mycoplasma)
  • Drugs (NSAIDS, Sulfonamides, antiepileptics, antibiotics,antimalarials)

Symptoms

  • Target-like lesions: The rash often appears as target-like lesions with three distinct zones of color.
  • Itching and burning: The lesions can be itchy and burning.
  • Fever and malaise: In severe cases, EM may be accompanied by fever, fatigue, and joint pain.

Treatment : Conservative

Option A : Celiac Disease is associated with Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Option B : ITP Have Characteristics Purpura lesions.

Option D : Leukemia May Present with multiple tender erythematous skin lesions due to Neutrophilic Infiltration aka Sweet Syndrome.

Key Takeaway :

Erythema multiforme :

  • Cutaneous Reaction
  • MC Infection trigger : HSV 1 infection.
  • Lesion : Target lesions. (Site: Palms and soles).

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number-31.18

questions.text: A child presented with a sore throat and fever and was prescribed a medicine, after which he followed up with this rash. Which is the causative drug?
questions.solution:
The image shows erythematous maculopapular rash over the trunk.

Ampicillin rash :

In 5 - 10% patient

Association- Infectious mononucleosis (fever + Sore throat + Cervical / neck swelling)

Other association- Lymphocytic leukemia

Clinical feature- Maculopapular rash on the trunk, which spreads peripherally

It is non allergic, benign phenomenon

Ampicillin can be administered again in the future

Option B, C & D : Those Drugs are Not Related in Causing Rash In Infectious Mononucleosis patients.

Key Takeaway :

Infectious Mononucleosis Patient on Receiving Ampicillin Characteristic Centripetal Maculopapular Rash Occurs. It's Benign Phenomenon and Ampicillin can be administered in Future.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:119.2
